results_summary: Both interventions (package size cap and energy reduction) resulted in reduced mean body weight and gained Health-Adjusted Life Years (HALYs), with cost-effectiveness analyses showing they were "dominant" (cost-saving and health-beneficial).
population_specificity: 2010 Australia population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how different bottle sizes of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) influence in-home consumption behaviors and perceptions.
results_summary: The study found that smaller bottles (250 ml) increased drinking frequency and encouraged successive consumption due to convenience, perceived insufficient quantity, and positive attitudes. Some participants reported reduced consumption, but this was linked to practical dislikes rather than intentional control.
population_specificity: Sixteen households in Cambridge, England.
effective_dosage: Weekly cola supply in one of four bottle sizes: 1500 ml, 1000 ml, 500 ml, or 250 ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess pediatric dentists' attitudes, behaviors, and barriers regarding interventions to reduce children's consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) and prevent childhood obesity.
results_summary: Nearly 94% of pediatric dentists provide interventions or information on SSB consumption, but significant barriers include insufficient time and lack of health professional education. The study also found that most dentists view SSB-related interventions as integral to pediatric dental care.
population_specificity: Pediatric dentists and pediatric dental residents in the US (convenience sample of ~7,450).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption and obesity in type 2 diabetes (T2DM) patients.
results_summary: The study found no correlation between SSB intake and general obesity (BMI), but abdominal obesity (waist circumference) was significantly associated with higher SSB consumption (≥1 serving/week). Ex-smokers had higher SSB intake compared to non-smokers, and lower SSB drinkers had higher fiber intake.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes not on insulin treatment.
effective_dosage: Mean SSB intake was 0.6 serving/day (145.6 mL/day); subgroups analyzed were ≥1 serving/week and ≥3 servings/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a mass media campaign on reducing sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption and changing public beliefs about their health risks.
results_summary: The campaign increased awareness of SSB health risks, with 53% of respondents postcampaign believing SSBs cause heart disease and 75% considering them a "big cause of diabetes." SSB sales decreased by 3.4% in the intervention area relative to the comparison area.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 to 45 years in the Tri-Cities region of northeast Tennessee, southwest Virginia, and southeast Kentucky.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a trial investigating whether presenting sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) in smaller bottle sizes reduces consumption at home.
results_summary: The abstract describes the planned methodology for a preliminary study but does not report results, as it focuses on assessing feasibility for a future trial.
population_specificity: Households in Cambridgeshire, UK, that purchase at least 2 liters of regular cola drinks per week.
effective_dosage: The total amount of cola delivered was based on typical weekly purchasing, packaged in bottles of 1500 ml, 1000 ml, 500 ml, or 250 ml.
study_duration: Each intervention (bottle size) was administered for one week, with a crossover design totaling four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the impact of a 20% sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) sales tax on caries increment, treatment costs, and tax revenue in Germany.
results_summary: A 20% SSB tax reduced sugar consumption, caries increment, and treatment costs, particularly in younger and low-income individuals, while generating significant tax revenue. The reductions were more pronounced in males and younger age groups.
population_specificity: German population aged 14 to 79 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether low-GI sugar-sweetened beverages (isomaltulose) compared to high-GI SSBs (maltodextrin-sucrose) had beneficial effects on arterial stiffness and metabolic responses during low-physical activity.
results_summary: Low-GI SSBs prolonged postprandial vasodilatation and increased GLP-1 secretion compared to high-GI SSBs. Low-GI SSBs also attenuated impaired insulin sensitivity caused by low-physical activity, but arterial stiffness was unaffected.
population_specificity: 13 healthy men (age: 23.7 ± 2.2 years, BMI: 23.6 ± 1.9 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: SSBs provided 20% of daily energy requirements.
study_duration: 1 week per intervention (low-GI and high-GI SSBs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of conducting a randomized controlled trial to evaluate how different bottle sizes of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) affect in-home consumption.
results_summary: The study found that the trial procedures were feasible and acceptable, with successful recruitment and measurement of consumption. However, validity was compromised by external factors like guests consuming the cola and out-of-home consumption. Supplying larger volumes of cola was associated with higher consumption.
population_specificity: Households in Cambridge, England, that purchased at least 2 liters of regular cola per week.
effective_dosage: Households received cola in bottles of 1500 ml, 1000 ml, 500 ml, or 250 ml weekly for four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between chronic overconsumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) and risks of obesity, type 2 diabetes (T2D), and cardiovascular disease (CVD), as well as its prevalence and public health implications.
results_summary: The study found that SSB overconsumption is strongly linked to obesity, T2D, and CVD risk, exacerbates intra-abdominal obesity and liver lipid deposition, and is particularly concerning among children and adolescents. However, SSB overconsumption is often part of broader poor dietary patterns, especially in low socioeconomic groups, suggesting that broader dietary interventions may be more effective than targeting SSBs alone.
population_specificity: General population, with specific concern for children, adolescents, and low socioeconomic status groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of self-regulation interventions (implementation intentions and Go/No-Go training) in reducing sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption among adolescents with inhibitory control problems.
results_summary: SSB implementation intentions significantly reduced SSB consumption post-intervention, lowering overall calories, drink calories, and sugar grams consumed. No effects were found for Go/No-Go training alone, but combining it with implementation intentions reduced unhealthy drink choices.
population_specificity: 168 adolescents with inhibitory control problems over sugary drinks and foods, recruited from high schools in southern California.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether commercially available sugar-sweetened soft drinks (355 ml and 600 ml volumes) acutely raise plasma uric acid levels compared to fructose and glucose controls.
results_summary: Consumption of 600 ml of sugar-sweetened soft drink led to small, transient increases in plasma uric acid (13–17 μmol/l higher than glucose control). The fructose control showed similar increases (22–23 μmol/l), with no significant difference between soft drink and fructose effects. No volume-dependent difference was observed between 355 ml and 600 ml.
population_specificity: 41 participants (randomized into control and intervention groups).
effective_dosage: 355 ml and 600 ml of sugar-sweetened soft drinks, matched for fructose content (26.7 g in 600 ml).
study_duration: Acute effects measured at 30 and 60 minutes post-consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-GI and high-GI sugar-sweetened beverages on insulin sensitivity and fat oxidation during a period of reduced physical activity.
results_summary: Low-GI SSBs led to lower day-long glycemia and insulin secretion compared to high-GI SSBs, better preserving insulin sensitivity during inactivity, though fat oxidation was unaffected by the type of SSB.
population_specificity: 13 healthy men (age 23.7±2.2 years, BMI 23.6±1.9 kg/m²)
effective_dosage: SSBs providing 20% of daily energy requirement

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine where students obtain sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) during school lunchtime and whether purchasing SSBs during the school commute is associated with higher SSB consumption during lunch.
results_summary: Approximately 20.4% of students drank an SSB during lunch, with 23% of these obtained during the school commute. Students who purchased beverages during their commute were significantly more likely to consume SSBs during lunch (adjusted odds ratio 3.32).
population_specificity: Low-income, ethnically diverse middle school students (N = 597).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acceptability of government interventions (nudge and traditional) to reduce sugar-sweetened beverage consumption in the UK and USA, and to test if describing interventions as working through non-conscious processes affects their acceptability.
results_summary: Education was the most accepted intervention, while taxation was the least accepted; nudge interventions (portion size, container shape, shelf location) were intermediately accepted. Highlighting non-conscious processes did not decrease acceptability, and perceived effectiveness was the strongest predictor of acceptability.
population_specificity: Adults in the UK (n = 1093) and USA (n = 1082).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a school-based intervention could reduce adolescents' consumption of sugar-sweetened fruit drinks and influence parental dietary behaviors.
results_summary: The intervention reduced adolescents' intake of sugar-sweetened fruit drinks, particularly in those with low- to medium-educated parents, and showed potential effects on parental fruit and vegetable intake.
population_specificity: 1,418 adolescents (11-13 years old), 849 mothers, and 680 fathers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention (SIPsmartER) in reducing sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption among adults in medically-underserved rural communities and to determine if health literacy influenced outcomes.
results_summary: SIPsmartER participants significantly reduced SSB intake by 227 kcal/day and BMI by 0.21 kg/m² compared to the control group (MoveMore). The intervention was effective across varying health literacy levels, with no significant differences in retention or engagement.
population_specificity: Medically-underserved rural adults in southwest Virginia (93% Caucasian, 81% female, 31% ≤ high-school educated, 43% < $14,999 household income, 33% low health literate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine market trends and consumer behavior regarding sugar-sweetened beverages and non-nutritive sweeteners, questioning the necessity of government intervention like taxation.
results_summary: The study found declining sales of sugar-sweetened beverages in Australia and rising sales of non-nutritive sweetener drinks, driven by health-conscious consumers, suggesting market forces may address public health concerns without regulation. Public health advocates remain cautious about endorsing this dietary shift despite low barriers to change.
population_specificity: General consumer market in Australia (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if replacing sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) with water affects plasma triglycerides, weight, and other cardiometabolic factors in overweight/obese women.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect on plasma triglycerides in the intent-to-treat analysis, but secondary analyses showed reduced plasma triglycerides and metabolic syndrome prevalence among obese participants. The intervention increased water intake and partially decreased SSB intake.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women (BMI ≥ 25 and <39 kg/m²), aged 18-45, living in Cuernavaca, Mexico, with daily SSB intake of at least 250 kcal.
effective_dosage: Not specified (biweekly water deliveries and monthly nutrition counseling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interventions reducing sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption in children led to changes in body fatness.
results_summary: Six of eight interventions significantly reduced SSB intake, with some showing sustained effects. Replacement drinks and education programs reduced BMI and overweight/obesity risk, particularly when combined with environmental changes like providing water.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-18 years (sample sizes >100 per study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current evidence on the association between sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption and cardiovascular risk factors and events.
results_summary: The study found that SSB intake was consistently linked to vascular risk factors (blood pressure, blood lipid, and blood sugar changes), but associations with cardiovascular events like CHD and stroke were less consistent, with some studies showing direct associations and others not.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether providing concrete visualizations of sugar content in sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) reduces consumer preference and negative attitudes toward SSBs.
results_summary: The study found that when people could concretely visualize sugar content (e.g., as sugar cubes), they viewed SSBs more negatively and showed reduced preference for SSBs compared to abstract sugar information (e.g., grams). Interventions facilitating this conversion led to decreased SSB attractiveness and selection in favor of sugar-free options.
population_specificity: Not specified (general consumer population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a school- and community-based intervention (the 'water campaign') in reducing children's consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs).
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced children's average SSB consumption, SSB servings, and the likelihood of bringing SSBs to school, as reported by parents and observed at school.
population_specificity: 1,288 children aged 6-12 years from multi-ethnic, socially deprived neighborhoods in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of different types of sugars in sugar-sweetened beverages (SSB) on fatty acid metabolism in healthy young men.
results_summary: The study found that fructose in SSB increased fatty acid synthesis (palmitate), while both fructose and sucrose impaired β-oxidation flux, indicating altered lipid metabolism. Glucose did not show these effects.
population_specificity: Healthy young men with normal weight.
effective_dosage: Medium fructose (40 g/d), high fructose (80 g/d), high sucrose (80 g/d), and high glucose (80 g/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between inhibitory control processes and the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages among adolescents.
results_summary: Inhibitory problems on the generic Go/No-Go task, poorer affective decision-making on the IGT, and sedentary behavior were associated with sweetened beverage consumption in males but not females. The food-specific Go/No-Go task did not predict sweetened beverage consumption.
population_specificity: 198 adolescents (ages 14-17), diverse and not receiving treatment for eating disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption and blood pressure (BP), specifically assessing whether increased SSB intake is associated with higher BP and hypertension risk.
results_summary: The systematic review found a positive association between SSB consumption and increased BP, with 10 out of 12 studies reporting statistically significant results. Five studies noted a rise in mean BP, while seven reported an increased incidence of high BP, concluding that SSB intake is linked to higher hypertension risk.
population_specificity: Participants aged 12 years and older, with studies involving a total of 409,707 subjects.

study_goal: To analyze the effect of reducing sugar-sweetened beverages, carbonated drinks, flavored drinks, and fruit juices on adiposity indicators in children ≤ 16 years old.
results_summary: The study found that reducing sugar-sweetened beverage consumption led to a decrease in adiposity indicators and a reduction in the prevalence of overweight and obesity among children. Conversely, increased consumption was associated with higher adiposity indicators.
population_specificity: Children ≤ 16 years old

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the association between sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption and adiposity indicators in individuals aged 13 and older through randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found mixed results: one trial showed a small BMI reduction after SSB reduction, another linked a 355 ml/day reduction to 0.7 kg weight loss, one observed increased visceral fat with regular Coke consumption, and one found no adiposity differences between groups. Overall, the review suggested a trend toward SSB consumption affecting adiposity.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 13 and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to organize and evaluate epidemiologic research on sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) intake and its association with obesity, type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, and coronary heart disease/stroke.
results_summary: The study identified 77 relevant studies, with most focusing on obesity. It found significant variability in study designs, SSB definitions, and outcome measures, complicating collective interpretation. Over 30% of primary research studies were not referenced in published reviews, highlighting gaps in existing literature.
population_specificity: Not specified (general epidemiologic research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether reducing sugar-sweetened beverage consumption could slow weight gain in overweight and obese adolescents.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced BMI and weight at 1 year, but these effects were not sustained at 2 years. Hispanic participants showed sustained benefits, while non-Hispanic participants did not.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adolescents who regularly consumed sugar-sweetened beverages.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention focused on reducing consumption rather than a set dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent epidemiological and human intervention studies on the metabolic effects of sucrose-sweetened beverages (SSB), focusing on their association with cardiometabolic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that SSB intake is positively associated with increased risk for metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes, coronary heart diseases, and stroke. Human intervention studies showed SSB-induced fat accumulation in the liver, muscle, and visceral fat, elevated triglycerides, and enhanced liver lipogenesis, with fructose being the primary driver of these metabolic aberrations.
population_specificity: General human population (epidemiological and intervention studies)

study_goal: The researchers examined whether providing caloric information about sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) would reduce SSB purchases among Black adolescents.
results_summary: Providing any caloric information significantly reduced SSB purchases, with the strongest effect observed when caloric information was presented as a physical activity equivalent.
population_specificity: Black adolescents aged 12-18 years from low-income neighborhoods in Baltimore, Maryland.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between sugar-sweetened beverage (SSB) consumption and metabolic syndrome in an Iranian adult population.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between SSB intake and metabolic syndrome in either men or women after adjusting for confounders, contradicting previous findings. High SSB consumption was linked to higher energy intake but not to significant differences in BMI or metabolic syndrome prevalence.
population_specificity: Iranian adults (1,752 participants: 782 men and 970 women) from three counties (Isfahan, Najafabad, and Arak).
effective_dosage: Categorized as <1 time/week, 1-3 times/week, and >3 times/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether covertly replacing sugar-sweetened beverages with sugar-free alternatives affects body weight in children, testing the hypothesis that liquid sugars bypass biological satiation mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that replacing sugar-sweetened beverages with sugar-free alternatives could lead to less body fat gain in children, suggesting liquid sugars may not trigger satiation mechanisms effectively. The maximum predicted difference in BMI z-score was 0.72, corresponding to a 2.3 kg weight difference.
population_specificity: 642 healthy children (mean age 8.2, range 4.8-11.9) who habitually consumed sugar-sweetened beverages.
effective_dosage: One 250 mL can of study beverage daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to inform stakeholders about the health risks associated with sugar-sweetened beverage consumption in infants, children, and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that high consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages is linked to overweight, obesity, diabetes, and dental decay, recommending limits on SSB intake and promotion of water and non-sweetened beverages. Educational institutions should ban SSB sales and provide unlimited water access.
population_specificity: Infants, children, and adolescents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of sulbutiamine on streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy in rats, focusing on glycemic control, kidney function, and related inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine treatment reduced fasting blood glucose levels, improved kidney function tests, and decreased markers of oxidative stress, inflammation, and fibrosis in diabetic rats. It also attenuated histopathological changes associated with diabetic nephropathy.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and anti-asthenic mechanisms of sulbutiamine (Enerion), as well as evaluate its efficacy and safety for treating asthenic syndromes.
results_summary: The study found sulbutiamine to be highly effective and safe for treating asthenia, with clinically relevant advantages over alternative treatments. The review highlighted strong evidence supporting its anti-asthenic action.
population_specificity: Patients with asthenic syndromes (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether sulbutiamine could protect against testicular dysfunction caused by streptozotocin-induced diabetes in rats.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine reduced blood glucose levels, improved testicular function (increased testosterone, sperm count, and motility), enhanced histopathological outcomes, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, PKC), activated Nrf2, and inhibited apoptosis (increased Bcl-2, decreased Bax and caspase-3).
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the history, potential applications, and existing literature on Sulbutiamine's health effects beyond its original use for increasing thiamine tissue concentration.
results_summary: The study found evidence suggesting Sulbutiamine may have anti-fatigue, nootropic, and antioxidant effects, with potential applications in treating microsporidial infections and certain cancers, but noted a lack of extensive research and methodological concerns.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of sulbutiamine on fatigue in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Sulbutiamine significantly reduced fatigue scores in MS patients, particularly those on disease-modifying treatments (DMTs), with no serious adverse events reported. The improvement was observed across physical, cognitive, and psychosocial functioning subscales.
population_specificity: Patients with MS (18-57 years, mean age 37.2) experiencing fatigue as a predominant symptom, with no recent relapses and low depression scores.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulbutiamine could protect hippocampal CA1 pyramidal neurons from ischemic damage in an in vitro oxygen-glucose deprivation (OGD) model.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine significantly increased neuronal viability and improved electrophysiological properties, such as excitatory synaptic transmissions and intrinsic neuronal membrane input resistance, in a concentration-dependent manner under OGD conditions.
population_specificity: Hippocampal CA1 pyramidal neurons in an in vitro OGD model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to monitor the presence of sulbutiamine in urinary doping control samples to evaluate its relevance in sports.
results_summary: Approximately 100 out of 16,000 samples contained sulbutiamine, mostly collected in-competition, with concentrations exceeding 500 ng/ml, suggesting intentional use for ergogenic and mild stimulating effects.
population_specificity: Athletes (doping control samples from a Russian laboratory in 2009).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulbutiamine could reduce trophic factor deprivation-induced cell death in transformed retinal ganglion cells (RGC-5).
results_summary: Sulbutiamine dose-dependently reduced apoptotic cell death caused by serum deprivation, increased glutathione (GSH) and glutathione-S-transferase (GST) activity, and decreased expression of cleaved caspase-3 and AIF.
population_specificity: Transformed retinal ganglion cells (RGC-5) in culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic sulbutiamine treatment improves memory in rats, specifically in spatial and object recognition tasks, and whether it counteracts amnesia induced by NMDA receptor blockade.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine improved memory in the object recognition task but not in the DNMTS task. It also counteracted the amnesic effects of dizocilpine, suggesting potential benefits for working and episodic memory.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulbutiamine, a vitamin B analogue, effectively relieves asthenic symptoms in patients with infectious diseases when combined with anti-infective treatment.
results_summary: The study found that 51.7% of patients experienced complete resolution of asthenic symptoms, while others showed reduced severity. Side effects were rare (0.6%), and overall well-being improved significantly.
population_specificity: 1772 patients with infectious diseases and asthenic symptoms, recruited from 350 physicians across India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether sulbutiamine, when combined with an anticholinesterase drug (donepezil), improves cognitive functions in early-stage Alzheimer's Disease patients.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine improved episodic memory and daylife activities when combined with donepezil, while attention improved in both sulbutiamine and donepezil groups. Episodic memory declined in the donepezil-only group but improved in the sulbutiamine-donepezil group.
population_specificity: Patients with early-stage Alzheimer's Disease.
study_duration: 6 months (3 months initial treatment, 3 months follow-up with added placebo or donepezil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current knowledge on the effects of sulbutiamine in animal models and human asthenia, focusing on its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and target specific brain structures involved in asthenia.
results_summary: The abstract suggests sulbutiamine is effective in treating asthenia due to its lipophilic nature and selective activity on brain structures linked to the condition, though specific efficacy data are not detailed. The study reviews existing evidence but does not present new experimental results.
population_specificity: Patients with functional or organic asthenia (general population seeking medical help for fatigue).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sulbutiamine improves peripheral nerve function and symptom scores in patients with diabetic polyneuropathy.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine significantly improved electrophysiological parameters (nerve conduction velocity and compound muscle action potential) compared to controls, but symptom scores did not show significant improvement between groups. Glycaemic control remained stable in both groups.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with diabetic polyneuropathy recruited from a diabetic clinic in Malaysia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sulbutiamine on dopaminergic and glutamatergic receptor binding sites and neurotransmitter levels in rat brain regions.
results_summary: Chronic sulbutiamine treatment decreased kainate binding sites and increased D1 dopaminergic binding sites in cortical regions, while acute administration reduced kainate binding and dopamine-related metabolite levels. No changes were observed in NMDA, AMPA, or D2 receptor densities.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
study_duration: Chronic treatment duration not specified; acute effects measured after single administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of sulbutiamine (600 mg daily) in alleviating psycho-behavioural inhibition in inpatients with Major Depressive Episode (MDE) treated with clomipramine.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine did not show antidepressant effects but significantly reduced psycho-behavioural inhibition compared to placebo, improving patients' social, professional, and family functioning. Safety data indicated no significant adverse effects or inappropriate behaviors, including suicide attempts or mania.
population_specificity: Inpatients with DSM III-R defined Major Depressive Episode (MDE) treated with clomipramine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic administration of sulbutiamine improves memory and enhances central cholinergic activity in mice.
results_summary: Sulbutiamine-treated mice showed significantly improved performance in memory tasks 24 hours after partial acquisition, along with a slight but significant increase in hippocampal cholinergic activity.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sulforaphane elicits cellular responses consistent with being a fasting/caloric restriction mimetic.
results_summary: Sulforaphane impacted multiple nutrient-sensing pathways, increased mitochondrial mass and resistance to oxidative stress, suppressed mTORC1/2 activity, upregulated autophagy, altered glycolytic and TCA cycle intermediates, and activated starvation-responsive transcriptional programs.
population_specificity: Immortalized human retinal pigment epithelial cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose sulforaphane could reduce negative symptoms in antipsychotic-treated patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: Sulforaphane-treated patients showed significantly greater reductions in PANSS negative symptom scores compared to placebo, with a large effect size at 24 weeks. The effect was not mediated by changes in depression or cognitive factors.
population_specificity: Antipsychotic-treated patients with schizophrenia (DSM-5 criteria) in Hunan, China.
effective_dosage: 1,700 mg Avmacol Extra Strength sulforaphane daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulforaphane, when combined with a nanocomplex and sonodynamic therapy, could enhance antitumor effects in glioma by crossing the blood-brain barrier and inducing apoptosis.
results_summary: The study found that SFN@RB@SPM nanocomplex significantly increased apoptosis in glioma cells through ROS-dependent mechanisms, reduced tumor volume in mice, and enhanced innate immune responses. The combination of sulforaphane with SDT showed superior efficacy compared to the SFN-free nanocomplex.
population_specificity: Glioma-bearing mice and U87-MG glioma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effect of Sulforaphane (SFN) and its possible mechanism of action in ameliorating diabetes-induced cognitive dysfunction.
results_summary: SFN treatment significantly improved cognition, increased neuron count, reduced neuronal apoptosis, decreased oxidative stress markers (MDA), and enhanced antioxidant activities (SOD, GSH-Px) in the hippocampus and cortex. It also elevated the expression of Nrf2, HO-1, and NQO-1, suggesting activation of the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with induced cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the regulatory network and physiological mechanisms behind selenium-enhanced sulforaphane biosynthesis in broccoli sprouts.
results_summary: Se-treated broccoli sprouts showed increased sulforaphane and glucoraphanin content, with glutathione identified as a sulfur donor for sulforaphane biosynthesis. Key transcription factors (GATA22, ERF12-like, MYB108) were found to directly regulate SUR1 promoter expression.
population_specificity: Broccoli sprouts (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (Se application levels varied but exact amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Sulforaphane (SFN) on Streptococcus mutans (S. mutans) growth, biofilm formation, and cariogenic properties, both in vitro and in vivo, to assess its potential as an anti-caries agent.
results_summary: SFN inhibited S. mutans growth and biofilm formation in a dose-dependent manner by suppressing extracellular polysaccharide synthesis, acid production, and acid tolerance. It also weakened cariogenic properties and inhibited quorum sensing, with a rat caries model showing significant caries control and no observed toxicity.
population_specificity: In vitro S. mutans cultures and a rat caries model.
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of 256 μg/mL against S. mutans; sub-inhibitory concentrations were also effective.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sulforaphane on human acute myeloid leukemia SKM-1 cells, focusing on cell proliferation, cell death, and drug resistance.
results_summary: Sulforaphane reduced cell viability in a dose-dependent manner, with IC50 values of 7.0-8.0 µM, and induced autophagy. It had a weaker apoptotic effect compared to benzyl isothiocyanate (BITC).
population_specificity: Human acute myeloid leukemia SKM-1 cells (both drug-sensitive and drug-resistant variants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sulbutiamine in treating chronic postinfectious fatigue (CPIF) in general-practice patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant overall difference in fatigue reduction between sulbutiamine and placebo groups. A transient reduction in fatigue was observed in women receiving 600 mg sulbutiamine at day 7, but this effect was not sustained by day 28.
population_specificity: General-practice patients suffering from chronic postinfectious fatigue (CPIF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate sulforaphane's potential therapeutic benefits and limitations in treating mitochondrial myopathies, focusing on its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: Preclinical studies suggest sulforaphane may help mitigate mitochondrial dysfunction and muscle atrophy in mitochondrial myopathies due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, though limitations exist.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (not specified if human or animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulforaphane enhances the efficacy of chemoradiotherapy in glioblastoma by inhibiting thioredoxin reductase 1 (TrxR1) and promoting reactive oxygen species accumulation.
results_summary: Sulforaphane inhibited TrxR1 activity, leading to increased reactive oxygen species and enhanced chemoradiotherapy-induced apoptosis in glioblastoma cells. It also facilitated M1-like macrophage polarization, synergistically improving tumor sensitivity to treatment.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma (GBM) cells and tumors (in vitro and/or in vivo study; human or animal model not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Sulforaphane's potential as a treatment for metabolic syndrome by analyzing its effects on obesity, type 2 diabetes, and related metabolic disorders.
results_summary: Sulforaphane demonstrated promising effects in regulating fatty acid production and glucose management, with mechanisms including Nrf2 activation, NF-E2 activation, ROS reduction, and IRS-1 upregulation. However, more human studies are needed to confirm its efficacy in treating metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Studies included clinical and nonclinical investigations related to metabolic syndrome (e.g., obesity, type 2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the combination of quercetin (QT) and sulforaphane (SFN) inhibits breast carcinoma cell growth in MDA-MB-231 by targeting the ERK/MAPK signaling pathway.
results_summary: The study found that QT and SFN combined showed significant cytotoxicity in MDA-MB-231 cells, with an IC50 of 19.48 μM, increased ROS production, and enhanced apoptotic signals. The combination also inhibited ERK/MAPK/JNK/p38 signaling, suggesting potential as a chemotherapeutic agent.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 breast carcinoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sulforaphane mimics exercise-induced mitochondrial adaptations in skeletal muscle by activating Nrf-2 signaling pathways.
results_summary: Sulforaphane enhanced mitochondrial respiration, biogenesis, and dynamics, reduced reactive oxygen species emission, and upregulated antioxidant proteins, mirroring effects seen with chronic contractile activity. No differences were observed between exercise-mimicking stimulation and SFN-treated cells in mitochondrial and antioxidant-related proteins.
population_specificity: C2C12 myotubes (in vitro model of skeletal muscle cells)

study_goal: To investigate the protective effect and mechanism of sulforaphane (SFN) on acute liver injury in mice induced by diquat (DQ) poisoning.
results_summary: SFN reduced liver damage markers (ALT, AST), oxidative stress (MDA, ROS), and apoptosis while increasing antioxidant activity (SOD, GSH) and activating the Keap1/Nrf2 pathway, demonstrating protective effects against DQ-induced liver injury. No significant effects were observed in the SFN-only group compared to controls.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice (n=48, 12 per group).
effective_dosage: 5 mg/kg SFN solution, injected intraperitoneally once daily.
